attributes.title: Effectiveness and safety of Guilu Erxian Glue (a traditional Chinese medicinal product) for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis: a protocol for systematic review and meta-analysis

q1.value: Effectiveness and safety of Guilu Erxian Glue (a traditional Chinese medicinal product) for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis: a protocol for systematic review and meta-analysis

q2.value: Yuhao Si, Cenyi Wang, Yang Guo, Heng Yin, Yong Ma

q3.value: The prevalence of postmenopausal osteoporosis is rapidly rising, with a high proportion of patients being vulnerable to fractures and other chronic symptoms. The commonly applied Western medicine lacks cost-efficiency and tends to have a variety of potential side effects. Guilu Erxian Glue (GEG), an orally taken Chinese herbal product, has been advocated to manage osteoporosis for a long history. However, the evidence of the efficacy of GEG on osteoporosis seems to be less convincing and conclusive. Therefore, the purpose of this study is to assess the effectiveness and safety of GEG on postmenopausal osteoporosis.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will perform a systematic review and meta-analysis following the requests of the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses Protocols. The PubMed database, Scopus, Embase, Web of Science, Cochrane Library, China National Knowledge Infrastructure, Wanfang Database, VIP database, Sinomed and grey literature sources will be retrieved. Randomized controlled trials investigating GEG in postmenopausal women with osteoporosis applying osteoporosis-associated outcomes measures will be eligible for inclusion. Two reviewers will independently complete the procedure of study selection, data extraction and risk of bias assessment. A third reviewer will mediate when irreconcilable discrepancy happens. Should the clinical homogeneity exists, meta-analyses will be conducted. We will utilize the Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation to assess the strength of quantitative outcomes.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Our study is prior to the beginning, thus, no data exists right now.

question.value:
Inclusion criteria
Should studies meet the following criteria, they will be enrolled in our review:
1.	The study design was an RCT.
2.	The published language was in English or Chinese.
3.	The target participants were postmenopausal women diagnosed with osteoporosis, utilizing recognized diagnostic criteria. 
4.	One of the interventions was orally taking GEG, regardless of the dose, frequency and duration.
5.	The trial compared GEG with other interventions, such as Western medicine, aerobic exercise, education, calcium supplements and lifestyle improvements.
6.	Osteoporosis-related outcomes were reported, such as bone mineral density, bone formation or resorption biomarkers, falls and fractures. 
7.	Secondary outcomes might also be delivered, such as quality of life and adverse events.
Exclusion criteria
Studies that meet the following criteria will be excluded from our review:
1. Participants were diagnosed with idiopathic osteoporosis.
2. A duplicate report.
3. Necessary data was unavailable to receive from corresponding authors.
Search strategy
The following electronic databases will be retrieved for potential articles, comprising the PubMed database, Scopus, Embase, Web of Science, Cochrane Library, and also Chinese databases, namely, China National Knowledge Infrastructure, Wanfang Database, VIP database, and Sinomed. Each database will be searched from their inception to May 2020. We will also conduct a manual search in the library of the Nanjing University of Chinese Medicine and Duquesne University in case of any missing literature. In addition, we will hand-search all the related references in potential articles for further identification. The MeSH terms applied for retrieving are closely associated with “Guilu Erxian Glue,” “postmenopausal osteoporosis” and “randomized controlled trial”.
Selection process 
Two authors (YS and CW) will screen the titles and abstracts of potential articles yielded in the search process against the eligibility criteria independently and in duplicate, then read the entire contents of articles and their relevant references for final collection recruited in our review. Any conflicts of trial identification will be resolved by open discussions and then judged by an arbitrator (YM). Moreover, the relevant information (including the reasons for study exclusion) generated in this procedure will be recorded in a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet (Microsoft Corporation, Redmond, WA). The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses Flowchart will be filled in after the completion of screening studies to offer specific information.
Data extraction and management
Two authors (CW and YG) will independently complete the data extraction and collection of the studies that have passed the study selection procedure. A brief and structured electronic form embodying the following information will be filled out. 
1. Study characteristics: author names, publication year, sample size, trial location, contact information.
2. Participant characteristics: age, gender, geographic population, number of each group, health status (with/without osteoporosis), diagnosis criteria if provided.
3. Study design: how the authors implemented randomization, allocation concealment, blinding and how they deal with the loss to follow-up.
4. Interventions: dose, frequency and duration of GEG intervention and other interventions, routes of drug administration.
5. Outcomes: osteoporosis-associated symptoms, fractures and falls, BMD, bone formation and resorption biomarkers, quality of life, adverse reactions.
Any discrepancy that cannot be solved by discussion will be decided by a third reviewer (HY). Besides, all the recorded information will be double-checked by another author (YM).

Primary outcomes: osteoporosis-related outcomes were reported, such as bone mineral density, bone formation or resorption biomarkers, falls and fractures. Secondary outcomes: might also be delivered, such as quality of life and adverse events.

Data synthesis
    The process of retrieving and gathering data will be recorded on a PRISMA flow chart. Meta-analyses will be administered to quantitatively incorporate data while studies with clinical homogeneity and low-level statistical heterogeneity. Groups of trials in which heterogeneity is rated low (I2 < 50%) will be pooled by a fixed effects model. Otherwise, a random effects model will be chosen. Continuous data will be analyzed by applying standardized mean difference or mean difference (with 95% CIs) if several measurements are involved. Dichotomous data will be merged utilizing risk ratios with 95% CIs. The results will be exhibited through forest plots and well-structured tables. Additionally, incorporated intervention effects will be estimated by employing a weighted mean of the intervention effects measured in the single studies.

attributes.title: Overall database of 98 studies on cognitive malingering
attributes.description: The present database contains 98 studies on the assessment of neuropsychological feigning. From each study we extracted a set of outcomes used to detect cognitive feigning in groups of normal and clinical participants. Subjects considered to be feigning were labeled mal and represented the experimental group, subjects considered to be honest were labeled hon and represented the control group. We selected 3 types of contrasts between groups: honest vs malingering (hon vs mal), malingering vs malingering (mal vs mal), and honest vs honest (hon vs hon). Two studies included an extra category of participants labeled indeterminate, which generated two new contrast possibilities: honest vs indeterminate (hon vs indeterm), and indeterminate vs malingering (indeterm vs mal). Test means and SDs were extracted for each group of participants, on each scale/indicator of included measures. Extracted data also includes: sample size of experimental and control groups, type of participants (normal/diagnoses for clinical patients), type of feigning, type of research design, type of investigated cognitive process, type of indicator used by the corresponding scale, type of detection strategy, and type of stimulus.

q1.value: Overall database of 98 studies on cognitive malingering for meta-analysis

q4.value:
If research designs moderate feigned performance, then we predict differential effect sizes for contrasts pertaining to simulation designs vs known-group studies
If the type of coaching moderates feigned performance, then we expect different effect sizes for symptom- vs test-coaching
If the type of stimulus affects feigned performance, then we predict differential effect sizes for tasks employing words, pictures, numbers, shapes, letters & symbols, or multiple stimuli
If the type of detection strategy on which instruments of assessment rely impacts feigned performance, then we predict differential effectiveness of strategies in detecting cognitive feigning

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Comparisons of effect sizes generated by 3 types of independent contrasts between subjects, analysed according to 4 moderators (research design, detection strategies, type of coaching, type of stimulus)

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value: 46 studies were selected from previous meta-analyses (Vickery et al., 2001; Sollman & Berry, 2011), and 52 additional articles were retrieved from online and reference searches, conducted throughout Academic Search Complete, Academic Search Premier, MEDLINE, MEDLINE with Full Text, Psychology and Behavioral Sciences Collection, and PsycINFO databases, for articles up to April 2019, using the keywords initially employed by Vickery et al. (2001) - "malingering" OR "dissimulation" OR "motivation" OR "deception" OR "feigning" OR "faking" – to which we added OR “simulation” AND ("neuropsychological assessment" OR "or neuropsychological testing").

q13.value: Our database totals 98 studies, separated into 109 entries

question.value: We measured the impact that the research design, detection strategies, type of coaching and type of stimulus might have on the detection of feigned cognitive under-performance
We used Comprehensive Meta-analysis V2 for Windows to calculate effect sizes, heterogeneity and  confidence intervals for selected contrasts

If the type of coaching moderates feigned performance, then we expect different effect sizes for symptom- vs test-coaching
If the type of stimulus affects feigned performance, then we predict differential effect sizes for tasks employing words, pictures, numbers, shapes, letters & symbols, or multiple stimuli
If the type of detection strategy on which instruments of assessment rely impacts feigned performance, then we predict differential effectiveness of strategies in detecting cognitive feigning

attributes.title: Figur Hukum Baitul Maal wat Tamwil (BMT) Sebagai Lembaga Ekonomi Kerakyatan
attributes.description:
Buku ini mengkaji aspek hukum Baitul Maal wat Tamwil (BMT) yang diawali dengan uraian mengenai BMT sebagai Lembaga Keuangan Mikro Syariah. BMT juga merupakan salah satu model sistem ekonomi kerakyatan yang perkembangannya dapat menopang percepatan pertumbuhan ekonomi nasional, namun secara yuridis, BMT didirikan dan dikembangkan dengan suatu proses legalitas hukum yang bertahap. Status BMT ditentukan oleh jumlah aset yang dimiliki, maka BMT memiliki status hukum yang berbeda pula sesuai dengan tahapan jumlah aset tersebut, serta tunduk pada hukum yang beragam dan parsial sesuai dengan tahap status hukum. Untuk itu, dalam buku ini, Penulis akan menguraikan konsep hukum pengaturan lembaga BMT di masa yang akan datang. 
Buku ini diharapakan memenuhi kebutuhan, baik akademisi maupun praktisi yang berminat mengkaji aspek hukum BMT, serta mahasiswa Fakultas Hukum, Fakultas Syariah, Fakultas Ekonomi, dan mahasiswa program Pascasarjana Bidang Kajian Utama Hukum Bisnis.

Untuk itu, dalam buku ini, Penulis akan menguraikan konsep hukum pengaturan lembaga BMT di masa yang akan datang. 
Buku ini diharapakan memenuhi kebutuhan, baik akademisi maupun praktisi yang berminat mengkaji aspek hukum BMT, serta mahasiswa Fakultas Hukum, Fakultas Syariah, Fakultas Ekonomi, dan mahasiswa program Pascasarjana Bidang Kajian Utama Hukum Bisnis.

attributes.title: Replication of Comparative Studies of Detecting Abusive Language on Twitter
attributes.description: This is the replication project for the Winter 2020 Data Reproducibility course in the Master of Data Science program at University of Washington.
